And, if you watch closely on the last series of pictures, you can see the two guys because they didn't move a lot and have been "printed" to the sensor.

Sorry my english is not good. Is that clear enough ?

If the brighter object were not moving, they would have "burned" the sensor because over-exposing, meaning that you expose for a longer time an object that doesn't need it, resulting in lost of colors and precision. You can see that in the frisbee picture where the frisbee stayed in place for too long (on the right side of the picture) and the ray is lighter and brighter.

So, if you expose during 10 sec, and you move in the frame during that time, you'll be either blurry, or completely absent because you are becoming the extreme of blurry : invisible.
But, if the object is brighter (a torchlight, a fireball or a frisbee), the light of the said object will be printed directly to the sensor during the whole time of exposition, because the object contain enought light to do so.
That's why you can see here only the bright moving objects and the motionless background.

So, either you don't have enough light and you expose your sensor for a longer time, or you have enough light and you expose your sensor for a shorter time.

The time that you'll need to expose your object equal the time of the exposition. 
If you expose the sensor during 1 sec, you'll need your object to stay still during that time, or else it will be blurry.
If you expose the sensor during 10 sec, you'll need your object to stay still during that time, or else it will be blurry.

Hi there, I don't know if someone answered to you but here is an simple answer :
Actually this is elementary photography.
To fix an image on the camera's sensor, you need enought light to "print" the image on the sensor. (here, it is digital but the idea is the same)
Light is everywhere everytime, even during night, because indirect light of stars, moon and cities nearby.

The background is captured because the trees in the back aren't moving so the camera has enough time to capture those parts. In some of the images you can see Destin and Sean as "ghosts". This is because they stayed still for part of the shot and then moved. The longer something stays stationary the more of it you are going to see in the final image. You see the ball and the Frisbee because they emit lots of light that is captured by the camera.

Long exposure usaully does not capture object in motion. Only when object is still for long like 5 secs or more in 30 secs shots will get into the final photo. Long exposure usually inputs more light from still objects like u see the backgrounds. But the frisbees have light and so get captured but people do not have enough light on them and so they disappear.

Because they are moving around in the shot in very low light conditions.  The background is visible because even though the picture is taken in very low light conditions, the long exposure compensates for this as it is the sum total of all the light in the shot.  The people are moving, so the net effect with them is like that of taking a normal photo in darkness.
The lights appear as normal because they produce a lot of light relatively speaking.
Vecous dey are guizards!
because they don't reflect enough light to be cought by the camera.

I believe the reason is that the camera has to adjust to capture a certain range of dark to light so the glowing object it so much brighter than him that they fade into the background.
If i am wrong I would be interested to know the real reason.
Also, they could have edited out the small traces of themselves, if they exist

The frisby glows so the camera reacts more to that, and the background is stationary so the camera gets the same light for a long time and reacts to that. But Destin and Sean don't glow and aren't stationary so the camera can't pick them up. Just like if something moves super fast our eyes don't get enough light where it was to "see" it, unless it is emitting a relatively insane amount of light
The people throwing the ball/frisbee are not 'lit up' for enough time for the camera sensor to see them.

That is correct yay

It is because they are moving so much and so fast yet not giving off their own light source. There are "ghost" images of them which appear when they stand still. The scenery is motionless so the camera is able to pick up it's image.

I could be completely wrong, but if you look closely at some pictures it looks kind of like a light transparent ghost, it's because the camera is taking pictures of that spot more than one time and whenever they move then the camera captures just the forest or the ground or whatever is there. They are moving a lot, and they are not producing any light so they aren't being captured.
that's awesome! :D
I think it's because they keep moving and not enough light stays on them long enough for the camera to actually put together a lightened picture.

Both of them are constantly moving; therefore, the continuous low intensity light that collects on the background is not enough to reaffirm the body's image.  The high intensity light of the Frisbee (etc.) is picked up regardless of position and time exposed.
Because they are moving all the time and the background isn't, so the camera can't catch enough light reflecting from them to capture them in the picture.

Because the shutter on the camera is open for such a long time, any light is amplified, this makes the background appear to be daylight, and this is also why the cool light effects from the frizbees and stuff appear in smooth bright lines.
Some cameras can do long shutter expose, it's a mode for taking photos of stars in night.

no, its one picture with one open and one close of the shutter.  The camera is on a long shutter setting (maybe 20 seconds or so). The longer the shutter is open, the more light is allowed in, which is why the scene is much brighter than when he was just shooting a video
yep, thats right

It has to do with the amount of light exposure.  The longer the shutter is open the longer the picture will be exposed to light therefore making the a pic with a 20 sec exposure time lighter than a pic with a half second exposure time.  He isn't in the picture because there isn't enough light to illuminate him.  If you look closely, you can see a very faded and almost ghostlike outline of him.

Yeah we could catch it.  Depth perception was a little hard, but we could do it.  Yes, it would peg us.  replay the video and you can see the 'drops' on the still images.

The camera had a small LED on the front to show it's recording.  Thanks for watching!  Try it yourself!

Could you actually catch the ball or Frisbee when it was thrown to you? Would it sometimes peg you?

Also, how would you know where the camera was when you were walking back toward it? Did your headlight give enough light to see it or did you have reflective tape on the tripod?

the trees had enough light to reflect? 
or did you have rear flash?

In short, we were moving and the trees weren't.  Since the exposures were anywhere between 30 and 90 seconds, we would have to be still for at least half that time for the chip to pick up anything more than a ghost image of us due to the weak exposure.
